description: Test scenario for experimental biology research in flagship journal

ThesisContext.title: CRISPR-Cas9 Mediated Correction of Sickle Cell Disease in Human Hematopoietic Stem Cells
research_questions: Can precise CRISPR-Cas9 editing correct the HBB E6V mutation in patient-derived HSCs with clinically relevant efficiency?
What is the optimal delivery method to maximize on-target editing while minimizing off-target effects?
Do corrected HSCs maintain long-term engraftment and produce functional adult hemoglobin in vivo?
contributions: Novel high-fidelity Cas9 variant with 95% reduction in off-target activity
Optimized electroporation protocol achieving 80% editing efficiency in primary HSCs
Long-term (18-month) engraftment data in immunodeficient mouse model
First-in-human safety data from Phase I clinical trial (n=6)

terminology_glossary.definition: Multipotent stem cells that give rise to all blood cell types
A genome editing technology using a guide RNA to direct Cas9 nuclease to specific DNA sequences
The gene encoding the beta subunit of hemoglobin
The specific point mutation (glutamic acid to valine at position 6) causing sickle cell disease
Unintended genetic modifications at genomic sites similar to the target sequence
The process by which transplanted stem cells establish and regenerate in the recipient

formatting.extended_data: Extended Data Fig., Extended Data Table

must_not_include: clinical claims without Phase I data qualifier
validation_criteria.expected_structure: Nature format (concise main text, detailed methods)
